resources.string: I have read and I accept these conditions

AtrapaelTigre is now Mosquito Alert!

We are the same team but the project has grown to incorporate a new character: Now you can send reports of not only tiger mosquitoes (Aedes albopictus) but also yellow fever mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti).

You can find more information at www.mosquitoalert.com

Thanks for your interest and participation,

The Mosquito Alert Team

string-array.name: gallery_array
string-array.item: Comparison of yellow fever mosquito (left) with tiger mosquito (right): The yellow fever mosquito (Ae. aegypti) has a lyre-shaped mark on its thorax while the tiger mosquito (Ae. albopictus) has a single white stripe.\u0020\u0020Foto: Vincent Robert (CC BY 2.0)
Tiger mosquito (Aedes albopictus). Its main characteristic is its black body with white spots and a white stripe on the head and thorax. Photo: Roger Eritja
Yellow fever mosquito (Aedes aegypti). In contrast to the tiger mosquito, Ae. aegypti has a lyre-shaped mark on its thorax and its body is generally dark brown. Photo: Mark Yokoyama (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0)
Observe the color of the abdomen of this female tiger mosquito: it is black with white stripes. Photo: Roger Eritja
Observe the color of this female yellow fever mosquito as it bites. Its body is dark brown, while the tiger mosquito is black. Foto: Mark Yokoyama (CC BY 2.0)
Female tiger mosquito ready to bite. Note the white stripe on the head and thorax, and the stripes on the legs.\u0020\u0020Photo: Roger Eritja
Female tiger mosquito biting. Note the characteristic white stripe on the head and thorax. Photo: Roger Eritja\n
Note the characteristic white stripe on the head and thorax of this female tiger mosquito as it bites. Photo: Roger Eritja\n
Who bites? Only female mosquitoes. Urban Aedes (Ae. albopictus/aegypti) usually bite during the day (not when it\'s dark), and they usually bite legs. Photo: Roger Eritja
Yellow fever mosquito (Aedes aegypti). Photo: Roger Eritja

Aedes laying eggs. The eggs are so small they are almost invisible to the naked eye. The urban Aedes ( Ae. Albopictus / aegypti) lay eggs the dry walls of small vessels near stagnant water. Photo: Roger Eritja
Aedes larvae (longer) and pupae (rounder). Notice that they are aquatic. The larvae emerge from the eggs when the eggs are covered with water, and they eventually turn into pupae. Photo: Roger Eritja
Aedes larvae (longer) and pupae (rounder). Remember to avoid keeping standing water around the house. Photo: Roger Eritja
Two Aedes pupae. This is metamorphosis phase from which the adult mosquito will emerge and take to the air. Photo: Roger Eritja

resources.string: Before submitting this breeding site report, please:
Before submitting this tiger mosquito report, please:
- attach a photo of the breeding site

This is the demo version of Mosquito Alert. With this version you cannot share data. If you want to participate in the project by contributing data, please click OK to install the full Mosquito Alert application. (If you already have the full version, you can uninstall the demo at any time.)
Use current location or select location from map?
Are you sure you want to delete this report?
Is it in a public area?
Does it contain stagnant water and/or mosquito larvae or pupae (any mosquito species)?
Have you seen adult mosquitoes nearby (<10 meters)?
Yes, stagnant water with larvae or pupae.
Yes, stagnant water, but no larvae or pupae.
No, neither stagnant water nor larve nor pupae.
Does it have white stripes on the abdomen and legs?
Does it have a white stripe on the head and thorax?
Tiger\u0020\u0020mosquitoes have a white stripe on the head and thorax.
Tiger mosquitoes have white stripes on their abdomens and legs.
Is it small and black with white stripes?
Tiger mosquitoes are small and black with white stripes.

HELP:
A tiger mosquito is small and black, with white stripes. It has a white stripe on the head and thorax. If you have found one, fill out this report and send in your data. Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.

  • Description: The questions here will help you decide if what you've found is really a tiger mosquito.

  • Location: Choose current location if you are still in the place where you found the mosquito. (Make sure you have GPS enabled on your phone.) Otherwise, select the mosquito's location on the map.

  • Photo(s): Take a photo of the mosquito now or attach one from a file. The most important thing is to photograph the white stripe on the head and thorax. To do this, grab the legs and focus well. If necessary, move the camera a little bit away from the mosquito. You can attach more than one photo, and it is useful if you can capture images from different angles.

  • Notes: Add a note if you want to send additional information about your finding.

Once sent, you can view and edit your report on your phone by selecting the map activity from the main screen and then clicking on a report icon. The information you submit will also be published map on a public tiger mosquito map at www.mosquitoalert.com .

HELP:
A tiger mosquito breeding site is a small, outdoor pool or receptacle of stagnant water containing mosquito larvae or pupae. If you have found one, fill out this report and send in your data. Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.

  • Description: The questions here will help you decide if what you've found is really a tiger mosquito breeding site.

  • Location: Choose current location if you are still at the site. (Make sure you have GPS enabled on your phone.) Otherwise, select the site's location on the map.

  • Photo(s): Take a photo of the site now or attach one from a file. If you can, take a picture in which the site can be recognized, and another showing the stagnant water and/or larvae or pupae.

  • Notes: Add a note if you want to send additional information about your finding.

Once sent, you can view and edit your report on your phone by selecting the map activity from the main screen and then clicking on a report icon. The information you submit will also be published map on a public tiger mosquito map at www.mosquitoalert.com .

A tiger mosquito breeding site is a small, outdoor container or deposit of stagnant water containing mosquito larvae or pupae, such as certain storm drains, basins, and fountains. They may be in public or private areas.

\n

Tiger mosquitoes to not breed on beaches or in rivers, lakes, ponds, or wetlands (although you may find other types of larvae in these places).

\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020\n\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020
Public areas are those with free access to the public, like roads, squares, parks, and green spaces. They do not include private lots and or other private properties.
The larvae and pupae need stagnant water and organic matter (food) to survive. Avoid letting water accumulate in or around you home.\n\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020
The tiger mosquito does not normally travel far, so adults are often found near their breeding sites.\n\n\u0020\u0020\u0020\u0020
This report has not been saved. Are you sure you want to exit?
No internet connection.\n\nTo view the feed, please connect to the internet and select \'refresh\' from the menu.
You have already completed this mission. Thank you!
Synchronize data with the Mosquito Alert server to receive new missions and the latest Mosquito Alert news.
Transmission error. Your data will be synchronized later automatically.
No internet connection. Your data will be synchronized automatically when there is a connection available.
Report deleted from phone but there was a transmission error. Your data will be synchronized later automatically.
Report deleted from phone but there is no internet connection. Your data will be synchronized automatically when there is a connection available.
Your locatioin cannot be detected because GPS and network receivers are both off. Please activate them or choose a location on the map.
Your location has not yet been detected. Please wait a few more seconds and try again or else select location from map..
Transmission error. Your data has been saved on the device and will be sent later. Thank you!
No internet connection. Your report will be sent automatically when there is a connection available. Thank you!
If you want, you can write a message here for the research team. For example, you can describe the\u0020\u0020mosquito in more detail.
Button for sending report to research center
SD card not available – data cannot be saved.
C/ d\'accés a la Cala St. Francesc, 14
Your GPS and network receivers are off so it Is not possible to detect your location. Activate them now?
If you select OK, your report will be sent to the project team and parts of it will be published on the public web map at www.mosquitoalert.com.
Will you send your mosquito by post to the lab?
Use this space to include a note or comments if necessary.
The photographs in Mosquito Alert were provided by R. Eritja (www.eritja.com).
